item.title: "Voters will have a chance to choose who will set the tone...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

"Voters will have a chance to choose who will set the tone for the criminal legal system in their judicial district. With at least half of the seats poised to turn over, the results could alter how — and how quickly — change will come to Colorado’s criminal justice system, which has been the topic of major legislation over the past few years.

“These people matter,” said Juston Cooper, executive director of CCJRC4Action, a nonprofit organization launched in September that advocates on criminal justice policies. “They are the gatekeepers. They are the reason we have mass incarceration and overcriminalization in the state, and in the country.”

#DAsAreCopsToo #CAAPV

At least half of the state’s 22 judicial districts will have new district attorneys on Jan. 1. Every district attorney seat is up for election this year, though many candidates and a handful …

denverpost.com

Half of Colorado’s district attorneys will be replaced after election, setting scene for future of criminal justice reform

At least half of the state’s 22 judicial districts will have new district attorneys on Jan. 1. Every district attorney seat is up for election this year, though many candidates and a handful …At least half of the state’s 22 judicial districts will have new district attorneys on Jan. 1. Every district attorney seat is up for election this year, though many candidates and a handful …

item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: "Ordinances that prohibit the life-sustaining activities of...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

"Ordinances that prohibit the life-sustaining activities of homeless people in public, even when there are no sheltered alternatives, criminalize homeless persons’ very existence. Moreover, these laws have the effect of increasing and prolonging homelessness at significant expense to American taxpayers. In the end, no interest is served and the entire community suffers." - National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty.

There are extreme disparities in the Denver Municipal Court system when examining race as well. Blacks are 9.8% of the population in Denver, but comprise 29.51% of individuals in the Denver Municipal Court system. The summary of research reviewing Denver Municipal Court cases while examining the effects of poverty, race, and mental illness can be found here: https://wp-denverite.s3.amazonaws.com/…/…/4/2020/08/OMPD.pdf

item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

https://www.denverpost.com/…/colorado-courts-covid-backlog…/

The ongoing threat from the virus, coupled with the unprecedented backlog created when nearly all jury trials in the state were stopped for more than four months, has put Colorado courts behind.

denverpost.com

Colorado courts face growing trial backlog due to COVID delays

item.title: today, #CAAPV remembers some of the governmental and police...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

today, #CAAPV remembers some of the governmental and police violence perpetuated on indigenous people. today, we remember the overpolicing of indigenous people. we remember the many times that the state has ripped children away from parents. we remember the many lives lost in the name of white, monetary gain. we remember the victims who have been ignored. we remember those serving disproportionately long prison sentences.

and we remember lezmond mitchell, all those who have come before him, and all those we fear will follow. we vow to continue to fight against the police violence that oppresses indigenous people.
https://www.nytimes.com/…/po…/lezmond-mitchell-executed.html

It was the fourth time this summer the Trump administration has carried out the death penalty. The case had raised issues of tribal sovereignty.

nytimes.com

Justice Dept. Executes Native American Man Convicted of Murder

It was the fourth time this summer the Trump administration has carried out the death penalty. The case had raised issues of tribal sovereignty.It was the fourth time this summer the Trump administration has carried out the death penalty. The case had raised issues of tribal sovereignty.

item.title: continuing this week’s #CAAPV #DYK: exculpatory evidence is...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

continuing this week’s #CAAPV #DYK: exculpatory evidence is evidence that “tends to negate the guilt of the accused.” evidence of innocence that prosecutors hide because they equate convictions to justice and because they care about winning more than the lives they destroy. #DAsAreCopsToo #EndDAImmunity #HoldCopsAccountable
item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: The only “new way of policing” we’re interested in is to...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

The only “new way of policing” we’re interested in is to #DefundThePolice. You can’t fix a system that is working exactly how it is intended and taking the very breath from our most vulnerable.

https://denverite.com/…/fired-aurora-cop-who-transported-…/…

Levi Huffine was fired after he transported a woman who ended up on his patrol car’s floorboard and asked for help.

denverite.com

Fired Aurora cop who transported Black woman who said she couldn’t breathe won’t get job back after appeal fails

Levi Huffine was fired after he transported a woman who ended up on his patrol car’s floorboard and asked for help.Levi Huffine was fired after he transported a woman who ended up on his patrol car’s floorboard and asked for help.
item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: this week, #CAAPV focuses on some of the myths behind wrongful...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

this week, #CAAPV focuses on some of the myths behind wrongful convictions. first, we begin with the somber reminder that wrongful convictions are rarely overturned and by acknowledging that many innocent people are in cages with all relief exhausted. wrongful convictions are rarely overturned because the system forever protects itself by prohibitively high legal standards that close the doors of relief and protect bad government actors.

prosecutors often say that exoneratio...ns are the system "working," because it shows that we are able to "catch our mistakes." in doing so, they completely ignore their own culpability in causing those wrongful convictions. they ignore how they used their power to cheat to win at all costs.

and most importantly, they ignore the human being who languished in a cage while lawyers frantically worked to bring their actions to light, on the dim hope that the courts might listen.

prosecutors are the architects of mass incarceration. they are violent cops who protect the police and put our most vulnerable in cages to attempt to silence their voices and to hide their own wrongdoings. and then they call that justice.

#CAAPV #HoldCopsAccountable #DAsAreCopsToo #EndDAImmunity

See More
item.author: Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

item.title: "Many people bitten were unarmed, accused of non-violent...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

"Many people bitten were unarmed, accused of non-violent crimes or weren't suspects at all. Court records show cases often start as minor incidents—a problem with a license plate, a claim of public urination, a man looking for a lost cat."

An Alabama man killed by a K-9 officer was one of thousands of Americans bitten by police dogs every year. Few ever get justice.

themarshallproject.org

When Police Violence Is a Dog Bite

An Alabama man killed by a K-9 officer was one of thousands of Americans bitten by police dogs every year. Few ever get justice.An Alabama man killed by a K-9 officer was one of thousands of Americans bitten by police dogs every year. Few ever get justice.
